papers.title: Socialization in Open Source Software Projects: A Growth Mixture Modeling Approach
papers.relevance: Examines how socialization processes including mentoring lead to contributor growth and retention in OSS projects

papers.title: The Onion Model: How Successful Open Source Projects Handle Newcomers
papers.relevance: Describes the layered community structure where experienced developers mentor newcomers through progressive integration

papers.title: Mentoring in Open Source Communities
papers.authors: Steinmacher, I., Conte, T., et al.
papers.relevance: Provides empirical evidence of how mentoring accelerates contributor development and progression in OSS teams

citations.reasoning: Multiple studies document how mentoring and socialization create reinforcing cycles of team growth in OSS communities.

papers.title: Core-Periphery in Open Source Software Development: A Network Analysis
papers.authors: Bird, C., Gourley, A., et al.
papers.relevance: Shows how core team members emerge from contributor pools and how this structure reinforces project sustainability

papers.title: The Evolution of Organizational Structure in Open Source Projects
papers.relevance: Documents how successful OSS projects develop leadership hierarchies through internal promotion mechanisms

papers.title: Leadership and Governance in Open Source Communities
papers.relevance: Analyzes how leadership development creates self-reinforcing cycles of community growth and sustainability

citations.reasoning: Research on OSS governance and organizational structure demonstrates how leadership development creates reinforcing feedback loops.

papers.title: Burnout in Open Source: A Survey of Developers
papers.authors: Rosa, G. D. A., Steinmacher, I., et al.
papers.relevance: Documents how burnout and turnover naturally limit core team growth in OSS projects

papers.title: Attrition in Open Source Software Projects: A Case Study
papers.authors: Nakakoji, K., Yamamoto, Y., et al.
papers.relevance: Early study showing how natural attrition balances team growth in long-term OSS projects

papers.title: The Life and Death of Open Source Software Projects
papers.authors: Schweik, C. M., English, R. C.
papers.relevance: Provides evidence of natural limits to OSS project growth due to developer turnover and lifecycle factors

citations.reasoning: Multiple studies document how burnout, career changes, and natural attrition create balancing feedback in OSS team dynamics.

papers.title: The Pull of the Mainstream: Challenging the 'Onion' Model of Open Source Community Structure
papers.relevance: Shows how promotion mechanisms naturally regulate the experienced contributor pool in OSS communities

papers.title: A Dynamic Model of Onion Layers in Open Source Software Projects
papers.authors: Xu, J., Gao, Y., et al.
papers.relevance: Presents mathematical modeling of how promotion between contributor layers creates natural balancing effects

papers.title: Community Structure and Evolution in Open Source Software
papers.relevance: Uses network analysis to show how core team size remains stable despite contributor flow in OSS projects

citations.reasoning: Research on OSS community structure and onion models demonstrates how promotion mechanisms create balancing feedback loops.

papers.title: Barriers Faced by Newcomers to Open Source Projects: A Systematic Review
papers.authors: Balali, S., Steinmacher, I., et al.
papers.relevance: Documents how onboarding processes regulate the flow of new contributors to experienced roles

papers.title: Newcomer Integration in Open Source Software Projects: A Systematic Review
papers.authors: Canedo, E. D., Calazans, A., et al.
papers.relevance: Shows how skill development and integration processes prevent indefinite accumulation of novice contributors

papers.title: The Hard Life of Open Source Software Project Newcomers
papers.authors: Steinmacher, I., Wiese, I., et al.
papers.relevance: Provides empirical evidence of how onboarding challenges and skill development regulate contributor progression
